title: Lab to determine the spring constant of a launcher

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Students are going to perform an experiment to determine the spring constant, <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, inside a spring launcher using the setup shown. They are expected to find <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup shown, which includes a vertical launcher with an ideal spring coil of relaxed length <math alttext="L sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and spring constant <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and a sphere with mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown. The sphere can be pushed down and secured with a pin, which can be pulled to launch the sphere. The vertical position of the pin can be changed. There is negligible friction between the coil, the sphere and the vertical walls of the launcher. (a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

frqParts.text: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Students are going to perform an experiment to determine the spring constant, <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, inside a spring launcher using the setup shown. They are expected to find <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup shown, which includes a vertical launcher with an ideal spring coil of relaxed length <math alttext="L sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and spring constant <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and a sphere with mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown. The sphere can be pushed down and secured with a pin, which can be pulled to launch the sphere. The vertical position of the pin can be changed. There is negligible friction between the coil, the sphere and the vertical walls of the launcher. (a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Briefly describe the procedure to be used to determine the spring constant, <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in the table and be sure to use the equipment identified in part (a).

(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the spring constant, <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how that information would be used to determine the spring constant, <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) In a second experiment students observe that the friction between the sphere and inner wall of the launcher is not negligible, because the sphere rolls while being pushed. If students follow the same procedure and analysis as described in part (b) through part (d) without incorporating friction, will the experimental value of the spring constant, <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the second experiment be greater than, less than, or equal to the experimental value of the spring constant in the initial experiment?

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
